text: Home > Grow > Gardening Tips > Cultivating Carnivorous Plants
label: BODY

text: Cultivating Carnivorous Plants
label: HH1

text: Carnivorous plants fascinate with how they lure, catch, kill and digest insects. There are more than 720 species of carnivorous plants, many with
label: BODY

text: astounding adaptations to inhospitable habitats. Popular carnivorous plants by genera include Byblis (rainbow plant), Cephalotus (Australian pitcher
label: BODY

text: plant), Darlingtonia (cobra lily), Dionaea (Venus flytrap), Drosera (sundews), Nepenthes (tropical pitcher plants), Pinguicula (butterworts), Sarracenia
label: BODY

text: (American pitcher plants) and Utricularia (bladderworts). With this kind of variety, there is no one way to grow carnivorous plants, but here are some
label: BODY

text: general tips to get you started:
label: BODY

text: Light. Most carnivorous plants prefer bright light, and many, such as Sarracenia spp., are best with direct sunlight. Flourescent or other cool
label: BODY

text: temperature grow lights can be used for indoor cultivation of smaller species. A terrarium of smaller carnivorous plants under such lights can
label: BODY

text: make a great starter set-up.
label: BODY

text: Humidity. Almost all carnivorous plants require high humidity. An indoor terrarium or an outdoor bog garden in humid regions will meet this
label: BODY

text: requirement.
label: BODY

text: Water. Do not use tap water or mineral water on carnivorous plants. Rainwater, melted snow or distilled water are ideal. Most carnivorous
label: BODY

text: plants require moist to wet soil in the warmer months and less moisture in winter.
label: BODY

text: Soils. Garden soil is not suitable for carnivorous plants. The preferred media for most are live sphagnum moss, dried long-fiber sphagnum
label: BODY

text: moss or a mix of about three parts peat moss to one part clean, sharp sand. Nepenthes prefer a more "open" mix, such as long-fiber
label: BODY

text: sphagnum mixed with horticultural charcoal, perlite, vermiculite or other porous aggregate.
label: BODY

text: Temperature. Temperature requirements vary with specis and some require a distinct cool dormancy period.
label: HH1

text: Feeding. When insects are not available, a one-quarter strength organic fertilizer will benefit plants when actively growing, especieally
label: BODY

text: Nepenthes. Do not feed any with actual meat, aas they are incapable of digesting complex proteins!
label: BODY

text: You can find out much more about carnivorous plants through the International Carnivorous Plant Society.
label: BODY

text: Source URL: http://www.usbg.gov/cultivating-carnivorous-plants
label: HH1
